answers.answer: Hi, I'll try to explain this tomorrow.  It's a component of INO, but I think it can stand alone.Quix

Hi,  I found this post on the site by looking up INO.  It's an expert response and I was wondering about your opinion.  It sounds like it may be related to my MS since I don't think I have any other health issues."its a cranial nerve problem.  there is no cure for BINO, you must treat the underlying condition.  someone has to figure out where the lesion is (which cranial nerves) and what the cause is, and fix it.  possible causes off the top of my head: lyme disease, diabetes, MS, aneurysm, compressive lesion (tumor), trauma, virus, myasthenia gravis etc etc.you need a full physical and blood workup to rule out systemic disorders."Thanks,Sally

I believe the acronym is short for intranuclear optic neuritis?  At any rate, what that means is that you either have a lesion on your optic nerve, or in the area of the brain that controls vision.  But most likely a lesion on the nerve - sometimes they can see it on the MRI.And yes, it is related to the MS.  I had optic neuritis as an initial symptom, and my right eye is still different from my left.  It sees colors as faded, light is darker, and I have more nystagmus in that eye.

question: Hi All,I have been diagnoised, but have a question.  When my Neuro first check my eyes and pupil reactions, she said the reaction to light was sluggish in one eye.  Has anyone ever heard of this?  I couldn't find this symptom anywhere.  Is this related to the MS?Thanks,Sally
title: eye symptoms
